page.title: 17LOCAL HISTORY
page.content:
Souldrop was originally a{Danish settlement called Souththorpe, the name gradually changed over the years to its present form. The earliest recorded{owner}was the Bishop of Coutances from Normandy in 1086 who came to claim the village in company with William the Conqueror.
Prior to the dissolution of the monasteries in 1560, the land belonged to the Melchbourne Preceptory, a monastic house of the Knights Hospitallers of Saint John. The area includes 350 acres of{common {land}enclosed by the Enclosure Act of 1770. It is reputed to be one of the last parishes in which{serfs}were employed.
